dt: {bc}a particular status or phase in which something appears or may be regarded

dt.t: They studied every {wi}aspect{/wi} of the question.
the threatening {wi}aspect{/wi} of the dark sky
… all that's best of dark and bright / Meet in her {wi}aspect{/wi} and her eyes.

dt: {bc}the position of planets or stars with respect to one another held by astrologers to influence human affairs
{bc}the apparent position (such as conjunction) of a body in the {d_link|solar system|solar system} with respect to the sun
{bc}the manner of presentation of a plane to a fluid through which it is moving or to a current
{bc}the nature of the action of a verb as to its beginning, duration, completion, or repetition and without reference to its position in time
{bc}a set of inflected {dx_def}see {dxt|inflect||1}{/dx_def} verb forms that indicate aspect

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}aspectus{/it}, from {it}aspicere{/it} to look at, from {it}ad-{/it} + {it}specere{/it} to look {ma}{mat|spy|}{/ma}
shortdef: a particular status or phase in which something appears or may be regarded
appearance to the eye or mind
a particular appearance of the face : mien

dt: {bc}a ratio of one dimension to another: such as
{bc}the ratio of span to mean chord of an airfoil
{bc}the ratio of the width of a television or motion-picture image to its height

shortdef: a ratio of one dimension to another: such as
the ratio of span to mean chord of an airfoil
the ratio of the width of a television or motion-picture image to its height
